data.text: Sleeping Bag for Minimal Style Bikepacking

Hi everyone, I'm just wondering what everyone's opinion on sleeping bags is and what kind you use for minimalist Style bikepacking. Mine packs down to about the size of a small basketball and it still seems to be too big to fit in my seatpack.
High quality down bag (800 fill power down) with a thin shell material, 15 denier or lower. But really the question is irrelevant without knowing your budget and temperature range.
data.author: Adie Mitchell

data.text: I have a 1 lb quilt I use during summer...packs down to 12oz can size
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: 1 lb 850-fill down quilt. High down number makes it easier to pack into a small size vs say a 650 filled bag.
data.author: Terrell Harrington

data.text: Depending on your temperature range.. the Sea To Summit Spark bags come in 3 different temperature ratings.. 850+ down fill, ultralight.. The 40¬∞ version is a scant 12 ounces and packs down smaller than a 1l Nalgene.

data.text: Cheap, packable, and lightweight‚Ä¶ pick two. I like Western mountaineering bags, they stuff very well and they‚Äôre light, and they cost about twice what the other brands do.
data.author: Jacob Buller

data.text: I really like my Western Mountaineering. It was expensive but the difference between a low quality bag was astounding. I got cold in 40F degree weather in my old bag, even while wearing warm socks and a base layer. In my WM bag, I literally almost strip down naked it's so warm. It's incredible how much better I sleep in it. I stuff mine into a 13L dry bag.

data.text: I bought the Everlite. It weighs under a pound, stuffs as small as I want it, and was only $320. It‚Äôs a 45F bag but is excellent for summer and fall, with some simple addons that get it down to about a freezing bag.

data.text: I like using the thinnest summer weight bag I can find, about the size of a grapefruit compressed. Just sleep in your clothes she will have on you no matter what.

data.text: Something really useful that I learned is that you can forego the stuff/compression sac and just jam the sleeping bag into your seat bag. I was able to get mine to stuff in the void next to my tent.

The mystic actually has a stretchy harnes that holds the sleeping pad in place and then they don‚Äôt put as much down fill in the bottom, pad is 3 1/2 inches thick, and packs up smaller than a Nalgene bottle, bag goes is 12L compression sack. Says this combo is good to 15 degrees. I haven‚Äôt used it yet if anyone has would love to hear opinions. Will be taking it to the Colorado trail sleeping above 10,000 sometimes. Hope I did good.

data.text: I have used a similar BA set up, just a bit older, and it has worked very well for me in temps into the 20s (I‚Äôm a warm sleeper) with a light wool base layer. The integrated pad stays in place and the sleeping bag (mine‚Äôs rated to 40F I recall) packs tightly. I was quite pleased when my valve broke on my old BA mattress and they sent me a new model just for the cost of shipping the broken one to them (about $12).

data.text: Pretty smitten with my quilt. I went with a Sierra Designs Nitro 35 for a combo of weight savings and comfort. I have a lot of their other gear and I‚Äôm really happy with the value for cost I get with them, but really any quilt-style bag will provide you a lot of weight and space savings.

data.text: Yes, you must use down. With a grain of salt on just how small it will pack. 12 oz claim, above, is not a liter, 2 1/2 times larger. Plan on at least a silk balaclava to retain heat loss from head, and clean thin wool socks to change into to reduce stink to your bag.

data.text: I use a down quilt rated to 32F. I sleep warm so it's good to probably close to that in the tent. Spendng $400 on a tent didn't make sense but the Seedhouse looks awesome. I am very happy with the quilt/Cloudup combo.
